Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Integrated Bioengineering Research, Education, and Outreach Experiences for Females and Underrepresented Minorities at WPI

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
This three-year REU site program will engage a diverse cohort of students in research projects within the intellectual theme of Bioengineering with a focus on innovation. Each student will conduct research mentored by a faculty member and graduate student on a project specifically designed for his/her abilities. The six participating faculty span multiple departments and have a strong history of involving undergraduates in research, leading to numerous awards, manuscripts, and conference presentations. To foster a strong sense of community amongst the students, the program will begin with a "Boot Camp" and all research will be conducted in a new multidisciplinary research center. Weekly workshops including creativity, communication, mentoring, and ethics will help the students gain professional skills and personal confidence critical for young students success in innovative research. A unique feature of this REU site program is that the students will be trained in mentoring for outreach to middle school girls in a week-long Bioengineering Innovation Program. The programs' evaluation plan focuses on desired outcomes, has multiple formative and summative elements, and uses valid and reliable instruments.

Broader Impacts
The proposed integrated training experience will not only expose a diverse cohort of students to research, but will also help them see how a scientific career can be possible for them as part of a rich personal life. Further, participants will appreciate how their involvement in science and engineering can benefit the next generation of students. The Principal Investigators (PIs) have developed a strong, proven plan for effectively recruiting from underrepresented groups of students and for providing authentic research projects that encourage confidence and self esteem. The innovative thinking fostered by this program will encourage students to think more broadly and creatively about the potential implications and impact of their work. For the middle school students, participation will increase their interest in science and their confidence in their abilities with the aim of increasing their retention in math and science courses essential for engineering careers. The programs' research results will be disseminated broadly through scientific and lay publications, conference presentations, and the Web, by the PIs, participating faculty, and students alike.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2013-2016, the Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI) Integrated Bioengineering Research, Education and Outreach Experiences REU Program successfully provided the opportunity for 30 female undergraduates from across the country, 53.3% of whom are minorities, to participate in meaningful, independent bioengineering research projects during their ten-week stay at WPI in the Life Science and Bioengineering Center, an open-lab concept collaborative research space.  Each student was individually mentored by a faculty member and a graduate student to lead them along the path towards independence in research.  The experience aided in the development of the students’ professional skills and personal confidence while encouraging creativity and innovative thinking.  The program also provided one-on-one mentored laboratory experiences for 49 urban middle school girls with the REU participants serving as positive role models. 

Throughout the three years of the program, evaluation results were used to inform decisions about its implementation. Evaluation data were consistently used to inform the practical implementation and actual and unexpected outcomes of the REU program.   Over time, positive results increased as changes were made and successful aspects maintained. The experience was a very good one for the participants, with 93% of the participants rating the program overall as “excellent” or “good.”  Participants described their experiences as “awesome” and “worthwhile,” and they stated that they “learned a lot” and “became empowered.”

The specific components of the program were also rated favorably, with graduate student mentors, research projects, and faculty advisors rated most highly.  The participants reported a meaningful increase in their independence as a researcher, and their faculty advisors and graduate student mentors concurred with their ratings.  They also reported that they gained ability to discuss scientific concepts with faculty research advisors and with other participants.  The participants noted that they gained an understanding of what everyday research is like and working collaboratively with others.  All participants submitted an abstract to the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) for presentation at the Annual Meetings and most were able to attend and present posters; a few participants presented at other relevant national meetings (e.g., American Society for Biomechanics). 

Along with research projects, a boot camp and professional development workshops provided opportunities for participants to increase their professional skills.  The participants’ self-ratings of their professional proficiency showed improvement in three areas: professionalism/ethics, poster presentations, and preparation in applying to graduate school.  They also indicated that they gained confidence in pursuing STEM studies/careers.  Further, most participants reported that they gained confidence in creative problem solving, another objective of the program.  The graduate student mentors were also trained in mentorship skills prior to the start of the program.

An Innovations in Bioengineering Week (iBME) for middle school girls was also successfully implemented by the REU participants and well received by the 49 girls who attended.  The REU participants were trained in mentoring skills, and also rated the experience highly.  Both group research activities and individual research posters were completed by the girls with one-on-one mentorship by the REU participants. They also participated in creativity/innovation programing in the afternoons. The girls reported that the program made them more interested in science.

Overall, our outcomes clearly demonstrate that the REU program provides meaningful research experiences and important professional development training for undergraduate students.  Structured mentorship training and outreach activities were also found to be beneficial for mentors and mentees alike.
